snippet: An employee in the office of the Brooklyn public administrator and three others pleaded not guilty to what prosecutors said was a scheme that targeted estates without wills.
abstract: Richard Paul, bookkeeper in Brooklyn public administrator's office, and three others plead not guilty to grand larceny; Paul allegedly wrote forged checks from seven estates, diverting money that was supposed to be deposited in the city treasury to himself and the three co-conspirators; Paul faces up to 25 years in prison.

headline.main: City Bookkeeper Charged With Stealing $2.6 Million From Estates
headline.print_headline: City Bookkeeper Charged With Stealing $2.6 Million From Estates

snippet: A man in Brooklyn fell victim to a scam, when he sold his iPad2 to a stranger in exchange for $420 in counterfeit bills.
abstract: Michael Wilson Crime Scene column on Brooklyn man who fell victim to scam when he sold his iPad2 on Craigslist to a stranger in exchange for $420 in counterfeit bills.

headline.main: For This Kind of Money, a Used iPad Proves to Be a Steal
headline.print_headline: For This Kind of Money, a Used iPad Proves to Be a Steal

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a Facebook founder criticizing a plan to finance entrepreneurs who don't have ideas yet, a report that Verizon s...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a Facebook founder criticizing a plan to finance entrepreneurs who don't have ideas yet, a report that Verizon salespeople favor Android phones over iPhones and numbers from Facebook.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Wiretapping the Web, and the App Lottery

snippet: Randall Stephenson, AT&T's chief executive, spoke about the state of the wireless industry at a conference this week, and he shared some surprisingly frank comments about the iPhone. He said he loses sleep over services like iMessage.
abstract: Randall Stephenson, AT&T's chief executive, spoke about the state of the wireless industry at a conference this week, and he shared some surprisingly frank comments about the iPhone. He said he loses sleep over services like iMessage.

headline.main: AT&T Chief Regrets Offering Unlimited Data for iPhone

snippet: Although most of the shares in Facebook's multibillion-dollar offering will go to large investors, a slice will be reserved for "the people." And a once-ambitious law firm has been reduced to grim dispatches. A look back on our reporting of the pa...
abstract: Although most of the shares in Facebook's multibillion-dollar offering will go to large investors, a slice will be reserved for "the people." And a once-ambitious law firm has been reduced to grim dispatches. A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.

headline.main: DealBook's Week in Review: The Stock Everyone Wants

snippet: Insiders cut through the chaos to offer easy-to-use cheat sheets for spending a week in Beijing, Hong Kong or Shanghai.

byline.original: By DAN LEVIN, KEITH BRADSHER and DAVID BARBOZA

snippet: A new weather app, Weather 2x, is the most elegant piece of mobile weather software I've yet encountered-especially on the newest version of the iPad.
abstract: A new weather app, Weather 2x, is the most elegant piece of mobile weather software I've yet encountered-especially on the newest version of the iPad.

headline.main: App Smart Extra: A Beautiful Way to Get the Weather

snippet: Congress should create national rules for corporations and establish uniform tax policies across state lines.
abstract: Op-Ed article by author Alex Marshall calls on Congress to create national rules for corporations and to establish uniform tax policies across state lines; asserts that in light of the controversy over news that Apple has avoided paying billions of dollars in state and federal taxes, the nation seems ready for such reforms.

headline.main: How to Get Business to Pay Its Share
headline.print_headline: How to Get Business to Pay Its Share

snippet: The Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade objects to the plan for “apple green” cabs.
Readers react to an article about how Apple keeps its taxes low while profits soar.

headline.main: What Apple Pays in Taxes, and Doesn’t
headline.print_headline: What Apple Pays in Taxes, and Doesn’t
